prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 0424 NGC 0526A in Band7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Search for outflows in the centre of NGC 0424 NGC 0526

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
THIS TECHNICAL JUSTIFICATION APPLIES TO ALL SGS OF THIS PROPOSAL
The main science driver is measuring the CO 3-2 transition, which may have line widths between 50-150 km/s, depending on whether it is measured in the outflow or the inner parts of the galaxy. While the predicted line width for the outflow is 150 km/s, the CO emission from the galaxy will be narrower and will be spatially resolved. We request a spectral resolution of ~2 km/s for the CO line so that we can fully resolve the kinematics of the lines in these brighter regions; for the weaker outflow emission we will spectrally average the data to ~50 km/s during processing to achieve the requested sensitivity. The sensitivity requested is dictated by the expected flux of the CO emission in the outflows. In our survey we will be able to detect outflows with molecular masses of 500000 - 1000000 solar masses. Our galaxies have distances in the range 40<D<150 Mpc: assuming a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of 0.5 10^20cm^{-2}/(K~km~s^{-1}) (i.e. Papadopoulos et al., 2012), a CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) ratio of 5 (ditto), a line width of 150 km/s, the CO(3-2) line intensity corresponding to a molecular mass of ~500000 - 1000000 solar masses at 40 and 140 Mpc, respectively, is 4.5mJy. The sensitivity we require is to obtain at a 5sigma level with a spectral resolution of 50 km/s. Simultaneously with CO 3-2 we will observe HCO+ 4-3 and SiO 8-7. These two transitions can be useful to study dense and/or shocked gas that might be associated to the outflows. In Arp220 the ratio between the CO(3-2) and HCO+(4-3) is between 5 and 10 (Sakamoto et al 2006). SiO(8-7) is weaker but the exact line flux estimation is complicated In addition, we added a TDM spectral window to observe the far-IR continuum produced by cold dust. The ~18 arcsec FoV of the requested Band 7 ALMA observations will cover from 4 to 15 kpc at galaxy distances of 40 and 150Mpc respectively. This will be sufficient to map the circum-nuclear regions where outflows are occuring for the Seyfert galaxies in our sample. The most extended structures we expect to recover will be around 5 arcsec on sky for the closest galaxies in our sample.
We want to detect structures of 100-300 pc (so we need the 0.5 resolution). the 5 arcssec max angular size is because we are interested in structures up to 1-3 kpc depending on the distance

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 5135 IC4329A in Band7

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe the CO(3-2) line in a representative sample of active local galaxies, drawn from the 12 micron sample, to detect molecular ouflows with masses 4x10^5-8x10^6 (depending on distance). We aim to measure what fraction of AGN-driven outflows can suppress star formation in their host galaxy. This has a relevant impact in cosmology because AGN feedback through ouflows can be an efficient mechanism to suppress star formation. We want to test the hypothesis of an evolutionary sequence from starburst- to AGN-dominated galaxies to explain the diversity of active local galaxies (Seyfert 1s, Hidden-Broad Line Region galaxies, Seyfert 2s, ULIRGs and low luminosity AGNs). Our sample consists of 17 galaxies proposed here, augmented to 33 galaxies including those that will be observed by ALMA and other interferometers. Based on energy budget computation, we identify the detected outflows that are AGN-driven and compare the mass loss rates with the gas reservoir to test if depletion occurs on timescales consistent with AGN duty cycles. We convert the number of outflows that satisfy these criteria into the number density in question and compare it with that of all galaxies.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, California at Los Angeles, University of
